prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: High-resolution Imaging the HD104237 gas disk

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our goal is to resolve the 12CO(3-2) disk around HD104237, which we detected in our single-dish spectra. SED and line-profile modelling indicate that the disk's extension is 90 AU in radius, or ~0.8'' at 114 pc distance. Using an angular resolution of ~0.22" in Band 7, we will be able to obtain over 10-13 resolutions elements over the area of the disk, sufficient to resolve the disk's outer radius. The disk being smaller than the 5.2 Maximum Recoverable of this configuration at band 7, there is no need for ACA observations.
The CO disk has an integrated intensity of 8.6 Jy*km*s-1 over the 6 km*s-1 line width. Assuming the CO intensity is distributed uniformly across the disk implied a flux of 0.65 Jy*km*s-1 per synthesized beam. For a spectral resolution of 0.42 km*s-1 we expect a line flux per beam, per channel, of 0.045 Jy or 45~mJy. For a signal-to-noise detection of 10, we require a noise level of 4.5 mJy in 0.42 km*s-1 , or 6.4 mJy in 0.21 km*s-1 allowed in our spectral setup. According to the ALMA sensitivity calculator, using 34 12-meter antennas we require a total of 46.2 min of on-source time to achieve the required imaging science goal. This implies a total observing time of 1.76~hours for this science goal.
We have used the CASA simulator in conjuntion with radiative transfer models to demonstrate that the imaging requirements are well met with the current setup and observing times, by simulating channel-map images of our CO disk model at the requested angular resolution (~0.22''). Our simulations indicate that the disk will be actually significantly brighter than uniform-brightess disk estimation above (which we use to set the limit in the integration times). Both the spatial and kinematical are well recovered with over SNR of over 30 over most of the image, and >15 on the fainter edges the disk.
Assuming a similar disk size for the continuum emission, the LABOCA flux (154 mJy) (154 mJy) implies a peak continuum flux of 11.6 mJy per synthesized beam. The continuum sensitivity achieved by our observations (0.06~mJy) will allow imaging the disk's continuum with a SNR of 200.
The correlator will be configured in the Standard Band 7 spectral configuration to cover the 12CO and 13CO isotopologues. The configuration allows to cover all desired spectral lines and a continuum windows, providing a good compromise between number of lines sampled, spectral resolution, and total bandwidth to achieve the science goals in relatively short integration times.
No special calibrations are needed. No special bandpass accuracy is needed.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Disk Mass Function in the 3-5 Myr epsilon Chameleon Cluster

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our goal is to measure the disk dust mass of the other member cluster. We request an angular resolution of 1" in order to match the expected continuum disk sizes (1-2" at 115pc). Disk simulations indicate this resolution could barely resolve the CO disks.
We will aim for a continuum RMS of 0.2 mJy which will yield 5-sigma detections at 1 mJy, corresponding to dust masses sensitivity of 0.37 earth masses. This continuum sensitivity can be achieved in 2.6 minutes per source in 4.4 GHz bandwidth. These integration times will yield 12CO and 13CO line sensitivities of ~20 mJy at the requested 0.21 km*smspectral resolution (or 15 mJy after binning to 0.4 km*s-1, which based on our disk simulations will yield 12CO detections with SN>5 (our model predict peak line fluxes of larger than 100 mJy/beam in each ~0.4 km*s-1 channel, with an image RMS of 13-15 mJy/beam in each 0.4 km*s-1 channel).
Our simulations show the uv-sampling is sufficient for recovering the disk fluxes despite the short integration times.
The correlator will be configured in the Standard Band 7 spectral configuration to cover the 12CO and 13CO isotopologues. This configuration allows to cover all desired spectral lines and a continuum windows, providing a good compromise between number of lines sampled, spectral resolution, and total bandwidth to achieve the science goals in relatively short integration times.
No special calibrations are needed. No special bandpass accuracy is needed.
All sources are located within less than 1~degrees so they can all share the same calibrations, making this an time-efficient project.
We note however that, since the sources in both science goal sources are confined to a less than 1x1 degrees**2 region, hence both science goals could be merged into one scheduling block by simply increasing the total integration time in HD 104237), and leaving the other targets with the 3-minute integration time required for the complete disk mass survey goal ( This is not feasible in the OT at Phase II, but is easily configured at the Phase 2 Generation stage. Thus, our two science goals can be achieved simultaneously maximizing the scientific output of this project with a highly efficient use of the ALMA time.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The study of disk evolution in the 1-10 Myr range is fundamental for theories of planetary formation and disk dissipation. Prior to ALMA, most studies concentrated in younger systems (t<1-2 Myr), as only the brightest disks could be detected. With its unprecedented sensitivity, ALMA opens a new era for studying disks at older evolutionary stages. We propose to obtain ALMA Band 7 observations to conduct the first deep submillimeter observations of disks in the close-by (114 pc), intermediate age (3-5 Myr) epsilon Cha association. These observations will allow to achieve the two following scientific goals: 1) measure the disk mass function in the epsilon Cha cluster, and 2) resolve the HD~104237 gas and dust disk to determine its main properties.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
